title: A CONVERSATION WITH: Dave Tarullo and Risha Druckman of Lōm Ceramics
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
A CONVERSATION WITH: Dave Tarullo and Risha Druckman of Lōm Ceramics

  • Colleen Russell
  • Apr 9, 2022
  • 11 min read

We stumbled upon the newly founded small batch porcelain and stoneware company, Lōm Ceramics, and instantly fell in love with their delicate craftsmanship, and knew we had to get our hands on some of their work.


Their collection of translucent porcelain luminaries have become an everyday ritual in our home to light, instantly warming the areas which are lucky enough to house them. We were so impressed with the quality and general ethos of Lōm Ceramics, and are thrilled to have sat down with the owners, Dave Tarullo and Risha Druckman, to hear more about their background, process, and inspiration.



What are both of your professional backgrounds and how did Lōm Ceramics come to fruition?


Dave: I have been working in clay for over 20 years, since I was a freshman in high school. It became my central focus after I finished undergrad. That’s when I started learning production pottery and slip casting. I worked under a master mold maker from Laguna Clay who taught me his craft, and spent time training in wood fired pottery, and sculpture before deciding to pursue my Masters, at the University of Montana. I was fortunate to work with three greats in the field of ceramics: Trey Hill, Julia Galloway, and Beth Lo. I taught ceramics and 3D design while earning my degree. After that I moved to Southern Arizona to teach at Cochise College and work with a a non-profit arts group called the Boarder Arts Corridor. I’ve been here in southern Arizona now for about five years.


Risha: My path to ceramics was much more circuitous than Dave’s. I earned my Ph.D in Environmental History and the History of Science from Duke University. After more than a decade in academia, however, I chose to leave my post-doc appointment in order to devote myself to my creative pursuits—chiefly music and painting. I wanted to prioritize those aspects of my life again; so I moved back to Arizona, took on more violin students, started painting, and began training in the art of millinery with one of the oldest hat makers in the country. The atelier and hat-making workshop here is very old world--filled with specialized antique tools that we use every day. And I discovered that the pleasure I derived from working with my hands as a hat maker, and later as a ceramicist, was akin to the pleasure I felt working with my hands as a musician, but toward a different end. When I met Dave, I was teaching violin and making hats for a living and painting in my spare time.


Dave had been working on a line of functional ware with two friends for a few years, and when that partnership dissolved I stepped in. We were dating at the time, and our conversations about how he should move forward with his line just organically developed into a business partnership. We would talk about forms and surfaces and Dave started teaching me the technical side of ceramics. We have a similar aesthetic sensibility, and our respective graduate school training means we approach the process of critique similarly, which is useful for developing work.



How do you divide & conquer when working together?


Dave: There are some fairly clear lines owing to our respective educations. Risha usually leads the way in glaze testing and surfaces, as well as marketing, styling, communications, and website work, and I usually focus on mold making, casting, and other technical aspects of the business, as well as packing and shipping work, (shipping ceramics without breaking them takes some finesse!).


Where we really come together is in design. Most of the time Risha comes up with an idea and we kinda toss it back and forth thinking about aesthetics and function and its feasibility before moving on to the next phase of production.



Do you have anyone else on your team, or is it just the two of you handling it all?


Risha: For the most part it’s just the two of us. Ultimately, we would love to bring people in and delegate more of our responsibilities so that everyone involved is not only doing what they love but what they do best, be that product design, mold making and production, web design, photography etc. There are so many elements to this business, it would feel really good to support other people in their particular line of work and specialization. We anticipate shifting more and more in this direction as the business grows.


That said, we are very fortunate to have a friend—Daniela Dawson—who we could hire to take product photos for our website, and we currently have a web and marketing specialist who is evaluating our site and making changes and recommendations…so the delegating had already started here and there, and the results have been great. We’re ready for more delegating haha!



Why Bisbee, AZ, and what do you like best about living there?


Dave: I moved here for a couple reasons: first, I was offered a teaching position at Cochise College where I would have access to a large wood kiln and the opportunity to teach students about this particular form of firing, which I’m really passionate about. Wood firing is a highly specialized and labor intensive form of ceramic firing in which wood is the only fuel used to heat the kiln. The kiln is stoked entirely by hand for the duration of the firing which can last up to a week and a half (day and night) reaching temperatures over ~2400 degrees Fahrenheit, (Cone 12). As an atmospheric form of firing, the ceramic surfaces achieved through wood firing are the combined effect of the flame and ash inside the kiln interacting with the clay. It’s an awe-inspiring process that produces incredible results, and not many community colleges have wood kilns, so it was a great offer.


Risha, by comparison, grew up here and after twenty years decided to move back to be closer to her family. So the quick answer is that that Bisbee is where we were when we started working together.


Risha: We both love the desert—the subtlety of its colors and seasons, the large expansive landscape and the feeling of space it provides. And we draw a lot of inspiration from the colors of the landscape here. I think people sometimes associate deserts with a lack of color, but that couldn’t be further from the truth: turquoise skies, red rocks and earth, yellow grasses, purple clouds at dusk…so many pastels! We take a lot of walks in the desert, and I love thinking about the relationships among the colors, and figuring out how to translate those relationships into our work.


I would also add that part of what drew me back to Bisbee was the creative community here. For a small town Bisbee has a remarkably vibrant and supportive artist community—visual artists, performers, musicians, poets, writers, potters….you name it. That said, Dave and I do sometimes question whether this is the ideal place for us to pursue this business, the relatively remote and rural nature of the town are not the first things that come to mind when one considers ideal locations for launching a small business. Dave is from Southern California, arguably one of the hottest ceramics markets in the country, and here we are in Bisbee! It’s kind of funny!…We’ll see what happens.



Is the climate of the southwest ideal for manufacturing ceramics?


Dave: The desert certainly has its advantages. Clay dries quicker in arid environments. It is surprising how important the drying process is, because as clay dries it becomes harder but also more fragile. Anyone who has worked in ceramics for a little while knows that timing is everything when it comes to clay. Knowing what things can or should be done at different stages of drying is crucial. You really have a specific window to perform each task. If you do something to the clay too early in the drying process the clay may not be able to support itself and fall, but if you wait too long the clay may be too hard to join or cut. Many, many pieces find their way into the recycle bin for this reason.


So, in the desert the drying process is sped up dramatically which allows for things to move quickly, but also limits the time each piece is in that sweet spot. Fortunately we can slow down the process by covering work in plastic or with a piece of fabric. The climate here is also good for slip casting (which we do a lot of), because the aridity efficiently dries the casting molds after each use, thereby reducing the amount of time the molds need to rest between castings. So we are able to cast more often than we would in a more humid environment.


Conversely, speeding up the drying process, for both clay and for molds, which people struggle with in more humid environments is certainly more challenging and takes more energy.



Is there a ceramics community in the southwest?


Dave: Aside from the region’s indigenous communities, who have a long tradition of producing beautiful work, much of the ceramics community in the southwest centers itself around colleges, universities, and community studios, as it does in much of the country. One of the things that makes ceramics unique from other disciplines is that it requires sizable and costly infrastructure, kilns, clay mixers, etcetera, which are generally easier for a collective (rather than an individual) to invest in, not only to offset the cost, but for reasons of space as well—kilns are big. And particular types of firing necessitate community as well. In wood-firing, for example the coordination of multiple people is often required because the firing is done entirely by hand, day and night, for days. Community is a necessity in ceramics and that’s one of the reasons I have such a deep love for it. Everyone has to come together to make it happen.


Our local ceramics community is quite strong and Cochise College has a lot to do with that. But we also have close relationships with people in Tucson, Phoenix, and up into the Verdi Valley where we wood fire at Reitz Ranch—the former studio of the renowned ceramic artist Don Reitz—which is now an incredible clay center.



Is your studio in or close to your home? How do you cultivate a sustainable work/life balance?


Dave: We’re fortunate that our studio is close to home—just five minutes away! In terms of pacing, wood firing lends itself to intense periods of making in the time leading up to a firing, followed by a period of rest afterwards. I’m not sure if that’s balanced, but I do think its pretty suitable for my demeanor, and it’s how a lot of artists tend to work. That said, clay likes to be tended to, so I’m in the studio about six days a week, often seven, regardless of whether we have a wood firing coming up or not.


Risha: We’re in one of those high pace moments as we speak—preparing for a wood firing in late April where we’re planning to fire approximately 250 pieces, while simultaneously testing colors and casting samples for a tinted porcelain line we’ve been developing. We’re also researching cameras and thinking about how we want to photograph this new collection, contacting stockists etc…it’s always a juggling act, but we’re both really passionate about the work and very deliberate in our pacing. I think what’s important is that the pace and intensity (high or low) is more or less a choice, rather than an imposition.



How do you conceptualize a new collection and where does your inspiration come from?


Risha: Our first collection started with a single piece: the Double-handle Paloma mug. It’s a beautiful, modern design, with soft curves, that feels so good in the hand, and we wanted to build off of those elements—the modernity, the simplicity, the soft curves, and its ergonomic emphasis. So that was our starting point. There is inherently more freedom at the start of a collection, and the parameters gradually narrow as the collection develops. The reason for this is that each new piece has to work with the forms that precede it, so with the addition of each new form the constraints increase—an elaboration on the general tenor of the collection as a whole, and in dialogue with the other pieces. In this sense, a collection tends to direct itself and tell us what it needs.


Conceptualizing a new collection happens in a similar way: in reaction to work that already exists. But in a new collection the trajectory points away from the current collection’s components rather than toward them. Our Paloma collection is cast, for example, with a sleek, modern ethos. In response to that, we’ve been developing a tableware collection that is thrown and decidedly rustic—the Baba set. Or take our Woodfire collection for example, which is extremely elegant. After our last firing I was hungry for something that felt more light-hearted and playful as a counterpoint. That’s how our tinted porcelain series started, in reaction to the current collection. The forms are the same but the surfaces are dramatically different—bright, cheerful, and painterly. This new porcelain series is also building on the tinted porcelain work we’ve done in the past with our luminaries, and expanding that conversation into functional ware.



How long is the process from design to conception on any given piece?


Dave: There is a lot of variation in how long it takes to create a re-producible form. Producing a piece that will be cast is a much longer process than creating work on the wheel, for example, and casting is the bulk of what we do. If everything were to go perfectly, which it almost never does, we could probably go from design to production in a month. In most cases it’s closer to three months. And in a few cases we have been working out a design for well over a year.



What do you find most challenging about your business?


Dave: I think for the most part it’s dealing with the nature of clay. I don’t think many people realize how challenging it is to create something repeatable and truly good. There are so many aspects and variables to making a successful piece. Countless tests of glazes and clay bodies all of which are significantly affected by application and firing type and schedules. But it’s also this amazingly complex puzzle and extremely rewarding when you get it all put together.


Risha: I completely agree. There are so many variables to consider with each and every piece: what making process is best suited to the form i.e. slip casting, throwing, or hand building, for example; what type of clay body to use; how to fire the work; what the optimal firing schedule is; considerations pertaining to design--functionality, proportion, strength etc; what surface you're trying to achieve, and whether it makes sense to color the clay body, or to use glazes, or underglazes, or atmosphere alone…and on and on.


It feels like a seemingly endless array of decisions and variables to contend with, many of which are at odds with one another. It's difficult to get all the elements to line up. And the stream of failures on the way to a successful outcome demands a thick skin—not my strong suit. I've had to adjust my expectations around results and time frames for completion and that's been really difficult at times. Maybe that matte surface I love is is a bad idea if we're trying to avoid scratching and staining, for example; or maybe the clay body I prefer just isn't a viable option because of its tendency to warp. All of these things take time to work out. And sometimes after months of testing and working toward a goal we find that it's just not going to work. That’s hard. I've had to let go of a lot of ideas that after trial proved inviable. As Dave said, however, the challenge is ultimately what makes successful final results so tremendously satisfying.




What do you hope the future holds for Lōm Ceramics?


Risha: In the grand scheme of things we are singularly committed to creating beautiful, thoughtfully designed handmade functional ware; and to nurturing our creative processes and inspiration. And while we aren’t committed to a specific vision of what that looks like in the long term, we do know where we’re looking in the short term.


First, we would like to expand our wholesale market. Pottery is such a tactile and intimate craft, and because every piece we make is one of a kind, and because we spend so much time in our design process thinking not only about function but about hand feel, we would like customers to have more places where they can experience our work firsthand prior to purchasing it. We want them to be able to pick up a pot and examine the surface and see how it fits and feels in their hand, and see how it sits on the table…things like this. We also view wholesaling as a way of mutually supporting other small business owners and makers, and that’s equally important to us. Seeing our pots in thoughtfully curated boutiques next to the work of other talented makers is gratifying for us on so many levels.


Second, we have also been developing two full dinnerware lines and we are excited to finalize at least one of those lines this year and to make it available to our customers—there are still some key details to work out but we’re close and that’s very exciting.


Third, we are interested in continuing to work with light via luminaries and lamps and we have plans to collaborate on designs with some friends of ours. We’re very excited about. Light is so full of magic and so important in setting a mood. And as a household with a penchant for interesting one of a kind lamps, the prospect of designing our own is a creative opportunity that feels really fun and inspiring, and we hope our customers will be equally enthusiastic about the results.



To shop the collections of Dave and Risha, please visit their website Lōm Ceramics.

title: COUPE GLASSES by AGUSTINA BOTTONI
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
COUPE GLASSES by AGUSTINA BOTTONI

  • Colleen Russell
  • Jun 28, 2023
  • 1 min read


Upon first encountering these coupe glasses designed by Argentinian artist, Agustina Bottoni, we were immediately drawn to their refined charm. Whether you're searching for a memorable anniversary memento or a tasteful wedding present, these glasses elegantly capture the spirit of romance, sophistication, and the simple pleasure of sharing special moments with loved ones over a delightful drink.


Our personal favorite in Agustina's coupe collections is the Nereida glass, which features a lovely and precious detail—a small sphere positioned at the center of the inside. This unique element is available in various colors such as green, pink, amber, deep blue, and clear. Each glass is carefully handmade in Italy by skilled glassblowers.


Agustina's studio offers commissioned projects spanning homewares, textiles, furniture, spatial installations, and set designs. Collaborating with local Italian artisans, she creates distinctive glassware and homewares that elevate living spaces and leave a lasting impression.


Items available for purchase online at Agustina Bottoni.

title: ROMA FLUTE SET by BELLARI HOME
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
ROMA FLUTE SET by BELLARI HOME

  • Colleen Russell
  • Sep 5, 2023
  • 1 min read

Updated: Sep 19, 2023



The Roma Flute Glasses, thoughtfully crafted by Bellari Home, serve as a delightful and stylish addition to elevate any table setting. With intricate hammered detailing and a touch of elegance through their gilded gold rims, these glasses transcend mere drinkware and transform into an exquisite statement piece that captures the eye and sparks conversation.


Bellari Home, known for its impeccable taste and commitment to quality, curates a stunning selection of timeless, minimalist, and earthy pieces. Each item is meticulously chosen to seamlessly integrate into any living space with grace and ease. Their collections are a harmonious blend of contemporary aesthetics and vintage accents, resulting in an ambiance that is both refined and luxurious, with a distinct artisanal charm.


Drawing inspiration from a rich tapestry of global influences, Bellari Home masterfully fuses styles, seamlessly merging the eclectic, modern, and traditional. This approach offers a harmonious fusion that caters to diverse tastes and preferences, ensuring that every piece they create becomes an embodiment of both beauty and functionality.

Incorporating Bellari Home's exquisite Roma Flute Glasses into your table setting not only enhances the visual appeal but also showcases a commitment to quality and sophistication that defines their brand. It's not just glassware; it's a testament to the art of tasteful living and an invitation to savor life's moments with elegance and flair.


Available for purchase in a set of 4 at Bellari Home.

title: WAVE CHAIR by RACHEL DONATH
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
WAVE CHAIR by RACHEL DONATH

  • Colleen Russell
  • Aug 7, 2022
  • 1 min read

We haven't been able to get these chairs out of our minds since we first happened upon them. The high end whimsy and playfulness they evoke instantly catches your eye. Handmade in small orders by artisan welders, and fabricated with a light weight metal frame and muslin upholstery featuring contrasting piping.


The Wave Chair is designed by acclaimed Australian furniture designer, Rachel Donath and inspired by the French modernist designs of Jean Royère.


Checkout the entire wave collection, available for purchase at Rachel Donath. (pictured below is the Wave Side Table and The Yoyo Stools)

title: PAGAN DINNER PLATE by ENZA FASANO
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
PAGAN DINNER PLATE by ENZA FASANO

  • Colleen Russell
  • Aug 1, 2023
  • 1 min read

We stumbled across this gorgeous plate set while visiting one of our favorite boutique stores in Brooklyn, Porta, which is known for its incredible curation of European tableware and assorted home furnishings from around the world.


The Pagan Dinner Plate comes in a set of six and is designed by multigenerational Italian ceramist, Enza Fasano.

Drawing inspiration from southern Italian folklore, her designs flawlessly marry uniqueness with a chic modern flare. Each plate bears a pagan symbol, inspired by the enchanting rooftops of Puglia's magical Trulli homes, adding a touch of captivating charm to every piece. Perfect for a housewarming gift as the symbols are believed to ward off demons and bestow good luck upon the residents, they add an extra touch of meaning and auspiciousness to the set.


Comes in a stunning navy glaze that's accentuated by a delightful ridge detailing along the edges. This thoughtful addition enhances its visual allure, introducing a subtle texture that elevates the overall dining experience.


Available for purchase at Porta.

title: CURVY RUNNER by CICIL HOME
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
CURVY RUNNER by CICIL HOME

  • Colleen Russell
  • Apr 20, 2023
  • 1 min read

The Curvy Runner from Cicil Home has captured our attention with its playful and chic design, bringing a fresh twist to the otherwise mundane category of runners.


Co-founders and textile experts Caroline and Laura are committed to using renewable materials and carefully navigating the production process. They source their fiber directly from a collective of farmers in New York, Vermont, and Pennsylvania and utilize the natural wool colors of Romney, Wensleydale, and Cotswold sheep. The wool is then cleaned in South Carolina before being carded, spun, and braided with Jute sourced from deadstock. Each braid is then carefully sewn by hand with 100% cotton thread.


Cicil Home's commitment to sustainability is reflected in their production process, where each piece is made to order. This not only ensures high-quality, long-lasting products but also reduces waste and promotes eco-friendliness.


The Curvy Runner is available for purchase on Cicil Home and comes in either soft grey or marble and available in custom sizing.

title: JEWELRY by HIROTAKA
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
JEWELRY by HIROTAKA

  • Colleen Russell
  • Apr 14, 2023
  • 1 min read

Hirotaka has long been one of our favorite jewelry brands, mastering the craft of minimalism while creating incredibly exclusive and intricately detailed styles. Each piece is distinctive enough to wear for special occasions, yet versatile enough to add to your everyday wardrobe. Their conceptual and abstract designs are meticulously crafted to seamlessly integrate with the scale of each creation, resulting in truly unique and harmonious designs.


In 2010, the Japanese brand made a striking debut in the heart of Soho, New York, with a modest trunk show that immediately piqued the interest of fashion editors and stylists. Featuring a unique blend of minimalism and edginess, Hirotaka's jewelry line boasted eye-catching pieces such as elegant pearl ear cuffs and intricate diamond bars that quickly gained popularity. Today, their avant-garde designs have taken the world by storm, with its jewelry line available worldwide and its first flagship store opening in Omotesando Hills, Tokyo in 2016.


Their latest collection, Miro, draws inspiration from the abstract paintings of Joan Miro and his aspiration to create dreamlike expressions. Hirotaka's wearable art is a playful reflection of this creative pursuit.


Jewelry available for purchase online at Hirotaka.

title: CERAMICS by KAREN TINNEY
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
CERAMICS by KAREN TINNEY

  • Colleen Russell
  • Apr 26, 2023
  • 1 min read

Karen Tinney is a Vermont-based artist known for her remarkable ceramics that showcase her creativity and innovation. Using glazed stoneware and intricate fabric fringe detailing, Karen's work is not only visually stunning but also functional.


Her artistic journey started at Parson's School of Design, where she developed a deep understanding of materials and their properties. In addition to her vases, Karen also creates beautiful mirrors and wall sculptures that are equally special. If you're looking for a unique and elegant addition to your home, Karen Tinney's creations are a perfect choice. Her passion for art and design is evident in every piece she creates, making them an excellent investment for any art lover.


Available for purchase at Karen Tinney.

title: SAKE WARMER by SSS
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
SAKE WARMER by SSS

  • Colleen Russell
  • Dec 17, 2022
  • 1 min read

Where perfect design meets functionality, the Sake Warmer from SSS is handmade in Tsubame, Japan, a manufacturer known for their advanced technology with sheet metal.


SSS is a Japanese company that strives to create tools and home goods that become more tasteful over time.


Keep your favorite sake or tea warm by pouring hot water in the reservoir and light a candle at the base.

title: 'STOP ME' BOOKEND by MONICA FÖRSTER
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
'STOP ME' BOOKEND by MONICA FÖRSTER

  • Colleen Russell
  • May 10, 2023
  • 1 min read


The 'Stop Me' Bookend, crafted by Monica Förster for Zanat, is a remarkable example of innovative design. The piece is skillfully carved from stained maple wood and includes a sophisticated leather handle, combining practicality with aesthetics. Its exceptional design makes it suitable for exhibition purposes or as a functional accessory such as a bookend or doorstop.


Monica Förster Design Studio, based in Stockholm, collaborates with various global brands in the production of furniture and home decor products. Monica is recognized for her expertise in using different materials and her remarkable sense of composition.


Zanat, a furniture and decor brand based in Bosnia, has been handed down through several generations with a central objective of producing designs that are of lasting value. They employ a hand-carving technique that has been acknowledged by UNESCO, as a means of safeguarding and advancing this craft which was once on the verge of extinction. Zanat works in partnership with designers who share their commitment to a design world that holds itself to higher principles of sustainability and community involvement.


The 'Stop Me' Bookend is available for purchase at Frank Bros.

title: HOLOCENE NO. 2 OIL LAMP by DAVID CHIPPERFIELD
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
HOLOCENE NO. 2 OIL LAMP by DAVID CHIPPERFIELD

  • Colleen Russell
  • Nov 20, 2022
  • 1 min read

Light is perhaps one of the most important elements in a home due to it directly relating to the mood you wish to set for yourself and others. Natural lighting is known to create an innate sense of warmth, as opposed to harsh, cold lighting. There's a reason we like candles in an entryway or bathroom.


Holocene's No.2 Oil Lamp brings a nostalgic twist on the calming flicker of a flame—brightening up any corner (or corners) of your home with subversive sophistication. With its moveable reflective shields that hug the base, this light is an elegant interpretation of the oil lamp, which allows the owner to have an interactive relationship to the piece. Made from both matte and shiny brass, it also features an off-center wick, which welcomes more moments of play between shadow, light and its surroundings.


Designed by David Chipperfield for Wästberg Lighting, a Swedish company founded in 2008.

Wästberg is dedicated to honoring the evolution of light and how we approach lighting design in the modern world.



"Electric light has been around for little more than a century – a blink of an eye in comparison with human evolution. Today, we find ourselves trying to tame our primitive needs to meet the demands of a modern, high-tech world, where light has more or less become a world of electronics. In our overly-lit spaces – created under the mistaken notion that more light equals greater productivity – we feel exposed, small, with nowhere to go.

We believe in creating modern-day fires. Light should shine for us, not on us."

- Magnus Wästberg, founder of Wästberg



Available for purchase at Wästberg.

title: MUSHROOM LAMP by STREICHER GOODS
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
MUSHROOM LAMP by STREICHER GOODS

  • Colleen Russell
  • Jun 19, 2022
  • 1 min read


Our love of checkerboard prints is married perfectly here with the retro Mushroom shape in our new favorite table lamp. Every detail feels purposeful. Down to the brass toggle switch in addition to its pointed top. It'll add just the right amount of playful ambience to any room.


Hand built in Brooklyn by ceramicist Ethan Streicher of Streicher Goods.




Available for purchase on Steicher Goods. $650 (shown above in a taller size option)

title: ALAI OLIVE NAPKINS by SANTA LIVING
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
ALAI OLIVE NAPKINS by SANTA LIVING

  • Colleen Russell
  • May 2, 2023
  • 1 min read

Santa Living is a distinguished Barcelona-based brand that came to fruition in 2019. It showcases a collection of textiles that draw inspiration from the stunning landscapes of the founders' homeland, namely César Carcaboso and Josep Vicens.


Among their magnificent range of products, the Alai Napkins stand out for their remarkable craftsmanship. They are constructed from pure linen, adorned with an enchanting embroidery detailing that exudes a contemporary, organic charm. Complete your tablescape by combining the Olive or Sand colored napkins with Santa Living's matching or contrasting tablecloths to elevate your dining experience to a new level of sophistication.


Santa Living envisions the home as a sanctuary of tranquility, providing a much-needed respite from the fast-paced urban landscape. Every textile from their collection is crafted with meticulous attention to the environment it will inhabit, taking into account its surroundings and the impact it will have on the planet. They collaborate closely with ethical suppliers and local artisans, utilizing only the finest organic-certified fabrics to produce their textiles.


Shop the full range of beautiful textiles on their website, Santa Living.

title: ARCA LAMP by PHILIPPE MALOUIN
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
ARCA LAMP by PHILIPPE MALOUIN

  • Colleen Russell
  • Dec 8, 2021
  • 1 min read


The portable lighting game has been growing immensely over the past decade. Philippe Malouin throws his hat in the ring with an abundance of style. His Arca Lamp is graceful and a notable silhouette for a kitchen counter, end table or really anywhere you please! The lamp comes with 4 settings - night, ambient, reading or task. You can tell function and form were on Philippe's mind when he designed this lamp. Make any nook shine with this simple yet stylish piece.



Available for purchase at Matter Made. $275

title: WOOD VESSELS by WALK IN THE PARK
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
WOOD VESSELS by WALK IN THE PARK

  • Colleen Russell
  • Jan 31, 2023
  • 1 min read


Wood will always be one of our favorite materials to source and decorate with. The multitude of tones and textures that are available never cease to amaze us. Upon discovering the collections of New Zealand based wood-working design studio, Walk In The Park, we were immediately taken with their modern interpretation and soft yet striking detailing.


Founded by artist Woo-Lam (Sam) Choi, who hand makes each of his designs in his Auckland studio. He began his wood-working journey in 2016 and is continuing his practice-led exploration into functional and sculptural objects.


The versatility and craftsmanship that’s displayed in Walk in the Park’s designs is unparalleled. Not to mention, with minimal care, these functional works of art will only get better with age. The final products are achieved using a particular technique called wood turning. The materials are ethically sourced and pay homage to the various types of wood that are available in New Zealand.





Available for purchase online at Walk In The Park.

title: TULIPIERE by ASHLEY PRIDMORE
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
TULIPIERE by ASHLEY PRIDMORE

  • Colleen Russell
  • May 2, 2024
  • 1 min read

Tulipiere vases originated in the Netherlands during the 17th century at the height of tulip mania. These distinctive vases were designed with a bulbous base to support the heavy blooms of tulips, which were highly coveted at the time. The tall, slender necks of tulipiere vases allowed the tulip stems to be displayed prominently. Originally crafted in delftware and faience, these vases became popular among the Dutch upper class as a way to showcase their prized tulip bulb collections. Over time, tulipiere vases spread to other European countries and were produced in materials like porcelain and glass.


We were instantly drawn to the Tulipiere vase designed by Ashley Pridmore. Its simple, structured form has a beauty of its own, even before flowers are added. Made from molded steel with a cream-colored resin coating, it utilizes a versatile and sustainable material. The sculptural feet provide an intriguing contrast to the slender body, their corner cut-outs ready to complement the delicate stems the vase will showcase. Its thoughtfully crafted design strikes a graceful equilibrium between visual allure and functional purpose.


Available for purchase online at Reed Smythe.

title: OPAL BEER GLASS by THE GOOD LIVER
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
OPAL BEER GLASS by THE GOOD LIVER

  • Colleen Russell
  • Feb 4
  • 1 min read

Some objects have a way of elevating the everyday. The Opal Beer Glass, crafted by a Tokyo-based glassware company with roots dating back to 1899, is one of those pieces. Delicate yet durable, it’s a nod to Japan’s deep tradition of fine craftsmanship—where form, function, and history seamlessly intertwine.


What makes this glass truly special is the rare Aburidashi technique, a process developed during the Meiji period that involves incorporating ash into the glass mixture. When exposed to rapid temperature shifts, ethereal white patterns bloom across its surface, creating an effect that feels almost otherworldly—like frost forming on a winter window or clouds drifting across the sky.


Originally a popular style during Japan’s Taisho era, this glassware bridges past and present, preserving an artistry that might otherwise be lost. It’s incredibly lightweight, thanks to the Katabuki glassblowing method, yet substantial in its presence. And with three distinct designs to choose from, each glass brings its own subtle variation of this mesmerizing opalescent finish.


Available for purchase online at The Good Liver.

images.alt: photos courtesy of The Good Liver

title: PAVE APEX RING by SOPHIE RATNER
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
PAVE APEX RING by SOPHIE RATNER

  • Colleen Russell
  • Dec 23, 2021
  • 1 min read

Updated: Jan 9, 2022




Sophie Ratner is an NYC based designer who specializes in delicate yet unique jewelry designs. This is a statement piece that is perfectly understated. The high polished 14k gold open band tappers gently with intricately set pave diamonds. The prominent diamonds are offset, drawing your eye to less traditional places. This kind of ring can be dressed up or down as an everyday ring—or saved for a special occasion.



Find this stunning ring and more, available for purchase online at Sophie Ratner, $670

title: THE CARROLL LAMP by ERICA MARIE
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
THE CARROLL LAMP by ERICA MARIE

  • Colleen Russell
  • Feb 3, 2024
  • 1 min read




The Carroll Lamp by Erica Marie Interiors embodies a striking dance of materials, meticulously balanced to infuse any space with a warm and inviting ambiance. The textured handwoven rattan shade, elegantly stacked upon its Italian marble base, becomes a canvas for the artistry of light. Adorned with intricate brass detailing, these elements harmonize seamlessly to establish a trifecta that defines the essence of this design.


Interior designer, Erica Marie, curates her own collection of products destined to be timeless heirlooms in any home. Drawing inspiration from the profound connection between an artisan and the significant role it plays in the lives of those who hold it dear, coupled with a commitment to sustainability, she excels in the craft of fashioning pieces that encapsulate beauty in every detail.


From the rhythmic interplay of materials in The Carroll Lamp to the broader spectrum of her creations, Erica Marie's work stands as a testament to the artistry of design and interior elegance.


Available for purchase online at Erica Marie Interiors.

title: GEOMETRIC SOY CANDLES by ANDREJ UREM
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
GEOMETRIC SOY CANDLES by ANDREJ UREM

  • Colleen Russell
  • Jan 5, 2022
  • 1 min read


Andrej's designs are distinct and unlike most candles you'll find at your local boutique. They are playful and unique, yet comforting due to their symmetry and adept usage of a milky white color. Hand poured in New York and made of eco-soy wax and lead free candle wicks, Andrej's candles are made with the help of a 3D printer.


It's hard to say whether you should burn this candle or not. But if you do "the flame burns a cylinder inside the core to preserve the exterior, leaving your wax objet d'art intact."


Available for purchase at AU Collection. $45

title: SMOKE BOX INCENSE HOLDER by HAND + FIRE
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
SMOKE BOX INCENSE HOLDER by HAND + FIRE

  • Colleen Russell
  • Jan 28, 2024
  • 1 min read


In the realm of artisanal ceramics, Hand + Fire, founded by Sage Cortez in Portland, stands as a testament to the allure of organic craftsmanship evident in each meticulously crafted piece. The incense holders are especially notable, distinguished by their captivating earthy tones and textures, making them standout choices and personal favorites for us.


Sage's artistic approach is centered on creating honest and true pottery that emphasizes the qualities of the hand in functional tableware. She draws inspiration from Japanese pottery and the concept of wabi-sabi, describing her work as minimalistic, organic, and distinctly human. Her goal is for people to recognize the importance of craftsmanship and appreciate the versatility of the human hand in her creations.


Her works are available online at Hand + Fire.

title: MAKI PLANTERS by OYOY
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
MAKI PLANTERS by OYOY

  • Colleen Russell
  • Mar 14, 2022
  • 1 min read


Oyoy's collection of Maki Planters are unique in their palette, design, and attention to detail.


Meant to be used as either a planter or for a variety of chic storage solutions, and comes in three different color ways, (black, clay and nutmeg), and in two different sizes. Made from 100% iron with leather detailing on the handles. Oyoy also designed a stunning sister product in a basket form for storage and / or firewood.


This Danish design brand was founded in 2012, and is know for their modern, functional, and long-lasting home decor and furniture.


Available for purchase at Oyoy Living Design. Prices vary.

title: ROLY POLY LAMP by AKARINO-TANE
author: Russell Nicolau
content:
ROLY POLY LAMP by AKARINO-TANE

  • Colleen Russell
  • Dec 26, 2021
  • 1 min read



The Roly Poly lamp glows by rocking it slightly and automatically turns off after 15 minutes. Designed by Rie Isono who had the idea when she had to put her child to sleep and fell asleep herself during the process. The hand made Hokkaido fir shade is thin enough to let light shine through it and gives off a dim rouge hue as the bulb gradually glows brighter. We love the acorn inspired shape and how it could bring about such an enchanting addition to a bedside table or a child’s bedroom.

Roly Poly Lamp was created by Akarino-Tane.


Available for purchase online at Nalata Nalata. $260
